Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was measuring the warped planks on Mrs. Lee’s deck. I knew it was Sunday—my day to call Mom and Dad, to tell them about my week and listen to Dad’s stories about his garden. I could already hear Mom’s gentle reminder: “Don’t forget to call, sweetheart.” But Mrs. Lee hovered nearby, her voice tight with worry. “Do you think you can finish today? We’re having guests tomorrow.” The deck was worse than I thought; it would take hours to fix, maybe all afternoon. I glanced at my phone, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in. If I called my parents now, I’d lose precious daylight and risk disappointing a client. If I waited, I’d break the promise I made to my family, the one that kept us close despite the miles. My hands tightened around the hammer, my heart caught between the pull of home and the demands of my craft, wishing I could split myself in two.
